titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the American Field Service Application Records
titlestmt.author: compiled by William Landis, Carol King, and Robert Bartels

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Sunday February 24, 2019 at 08:00

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The American Field Service Application Records comprise the history of an application filed in 1990 by American Field Service veterans of World War II for retroactive recognition as United States Army servicemen by the Pentagon under provisions of the G.I. Bill of 1977. The collection also contains research materials and publications relating to the history of the American Field Service during both world wars. The records, comprised of original documents, as well as photocopies thereof, were amassed by Joseph Porter Brinton, III, an ambulance driver with the American Field Service during World War II, who compiled the guide for their use.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Joseph Porter Brinton, III, 2008 and 2018.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to Yale University for unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator(s) of this collection. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: American Field Service Application Records (MS 1930). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Folders within the collection were retained whenever possible and provide copious notes, written by the donor, about their contents. The contents of these original folders were not verified against the label and notes written on the folders. Materials that were received unfoldered were foldered during processing by Manuscripts and Archives staff, and materials were reboxed for preservation purposes. The descriptions of the contents of each original box provided in this finding aid is excerpted from the donor's summary. Engaging with the guide (in Box 13, folder 1 of the original accession) compiled by the donor is a crucial first step for any researcher wishing to use these records. Books, journal articles, and other printed ephemera are listed at the end of the inventory for the first accession but are not arranged in any way.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Joseph Porter Brinton, III, was a member of Yale College, Class of 1945W. He received a BBA from Baruch College City University, New York, in 1957. Brinton was an ambulance driver with the American Field Service during World War II.
The American Field Service was established in 1914 as a volunteer ambulance corps. Its members, largely recruited from American colleges and universities, served in wartime Europe, primarily France.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The American Field Service Application Records comprise the history of an application filed in 1990 by American Field Service veterans of World War II for retroactive recognition as United States Army servicemen by the Pentagon under provisions of the G.I. Bill of 1977. The collection also contains research materials and publications relating to the history of the American Field Service during both world wars. The records, comprised of original documents, as well as photocopies thereof, were amassed by Joseph Porter Brinton, III, an ambulance driver with the American Field Service during World War II, who compiled a guide for their use.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The materials are arranged in three parts and one addition: I. Main business file (original box designation B), II. Main writing file (original box designation E), and III. Boxed volume files (original box designation VB). Within these parts, the materials are arranged as received from the donor. The donor's original box designations have been preserved in the inventory of the collection, and the donor's summary of the contents of each original box (with the exception of the VB boxes) is in the first folder within the original box designations.

controlaccess.subject: Ambulance drivers
Veterans -- Legal status, laws, etc. -- United States

did.unittitle: Brinton, Joseph P. III, "Guide to the American Field Service Application Archive," typescript

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This guide explains the organization imposed by Brinton on the Main business file (B), Main writing file (E), and Boxed volume files (VB) components of the archive. Researchers wishing to use the archive should consult the guide as a preparatory step.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This box contains earliest records of PL 95-202 applicants from 1981-1983. The first writing at the back of the box probably commenced in 1982. Content of missing papers can usually be deduced from adjacent records. The subjects include attempts to notify a disinterested and hostile AFS Corp., improper attorney report disowned by source, effort to obtain a current veterans address list, devious obstruction by Corp. Secretary R. Applewhite, test mailing to AFS veterans, report of results. No record was kept of unanswered notes to Corp. leader A. Howe. The extensive phone and in-person dealings with Applewhite were not recorded by us. The front of the box likely overlaps to a large extent with the content of B2 and perhaps B3. The information above was excerpted from notes supplied by the donor, which are in the first folder of B1.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Activity from first major mailing in February 1985 until the Department of Defense suspended PL 95-202 applications in 1988 and posted new regulations in 1989. Affiliation with AFS Corp. through Howe and Applewhite and creation of the AFS Veterans Committee in final form is covered, along with problems and dealings related to writing a PL 95-202 application. B2 contains a very large amount of historical research data and notes. Written research notes are very much curtailed because the researcher (Brinton) was forced to photocopy information, maps, and photographs to save time, rather than read carefully and write notes. The information above was excerpted from notes supplied by the donor, which are in the first folder of B2.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mainly 1988-1989 files relating to completion and submission of AFS application after new Department of Defense regulations for PL 95-202 were protested, but adopted. Then, the Army's Center of Miltary History produced a very sketchy, derogatory report that had to be answered. In addition, the back of the box contains a continued collection of folders devoted to individual AFS veterans leading the application or contributing to it. All formal notices and newsletters mailed between 1982 and 1991 are consolidated here. The information above was excerpted from notes supplied by the donor, which are in the first folder of B3.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mainly 1989-1990 files documenting conflicts among members of the AFS Committee as judgement of the PL 95-202 application approached. At the same time, Goodwillie and Brinton facing adverse questions and demands by the Air Force board in charge at the Pentagon. The information above was excerpted from notes supplied by the donor, which are in the first folder of B4.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Covers events from September 1990, when the founders dissolved the AFS Veterans Committee, until July 1993, when Senator Graham filed his pro-AFS entitlement bill, S. 1260, in Congress. The contents may include documentation on AFS decisions rendered by the Department of Defense PL 95-202 board, the adverse decision on the Graham-Brinton request for review in 1991, the decision entitling volunters in Burma with US 3rd CCS, the subsequent Department of Defense decision entitling AVG-Flying Tigers, and the Representative J. Tanner AFS entitlement bills submitted to Congress in 1992 and 1993. The information above was excerpted from notes supplied by the donor, which are in the first folder of B5.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials overlap B5 data on the effort to get approval from Congress, and run from late 1992 until roughly 1995. The effort to find a suitable attorney starts here with Howland in 1993. Documentation concerns many key decisions, laws, and summaries of AFS findings and claims to date. After Tom Hale reported the failure of Congress to consider supporting AFS entitlement, there was no further application activity until Cantrall filed a repeat application to the Department of Defense board in 1995. The information above was excerpted from notes supplied by the donor, which are in the first folder of B6.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains application follow up activity by Brinton from roughly 1995-2001. Most of the files are organized by subject, the most recent being Bissler's effort to employ military attorney E. Fidell in Washington. Also included are materials on George Bush. The information above was excerpted from notes supplied by the donor, which are in the first folder of B7.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains information about the work of Associate Editor William R. Cantrall, including research and advice that he provided during the period 1986-1990, and Brinton's assistance in Cantrall's ill-advised and ill-fated repeat PL 95-202 application to the Department of Defense board during 1994-1996. The information above was excerpted from notes supplied by the donor, which are in the first folder of B8.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains documentation regarding three different elements of AFS Committee application business: financial records; response sheets from AFS veterans; and address lists and other information regarding AFS veterans. The information above was excerpted from notes supplied by the donor, which are in the first folder of B9.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains outlines and drafts for the eventual AFS Application book copyright, circa 1988-1989. The information above was excerpted from notes supplied by the donor, which are in the first folder of E1.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains the first draft of the AFS Application text, and possibly some supporting research material. The information above was excerpted from notes supplied by the donor, which are in the first folder of E2.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains research materials gathered for the AFS Application, but for the most part not used. Includes documents, illustrations, and maps. The information above was excerpted from notes supplied by the donor, which are in the first folder of E3.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains partially organized research data used to compile the AFS Application book. Includes photocopies of overseas records regarding AFS veterans from the nascent, poorly organized AFS archive in New York City, and affidavits of AFS veterans illustrating service rendered to the U.S. Army overseas. Includes documents, illustrations, and maps. The information above was excerpted from notes supplied by the donor, which are in the first folder of E4.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains various versions of the extremely important summaries that the AFS PL 95-202 applicants composed and distributed to describe their wartime service. The information above was excerpted from notes supplied by the donor, which are in the first folder of E5.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains various copies and files relating to the AFS Application, including a World War I-era photograph of AFS ambulances in the field. The donor did not provide notes or summaries about the content of the original VB boxes. According to information supplied by the donor, box VB3 was donated to Princeton University Library, box VB4 to the Harvard University, Widener Library, and box VB5 to Harvard University Archives, Pusey Library. Box VB6 was distributed to libraries noted above. Box VB2 contained an exact duplicate copy of the contents of Box VB1 and was discarded.

did.unittitle: Books and other published research materials relating to the American Field Service

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Printed ephemera aimed at demoralizing Allied soldiers.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The accession is arranged into three groupings: publications, subject files and correspondence, and personal files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The accession consists of the American Field Service Application, filed in 1990 by American Field Service veterans of World War II for retroactive recognition as United States Army servicemen by the Pentagon under provisions of the G.I. Bill of 1977. The accession includes multiple copies and drafts of the application, as well as correspondence, research files, and personal files of Joseph P. Brinton III, who was heavily involved in the formation of the application.
